People with William's Syndrome often have green or blue or hazel eyes. Brown is uncommon in any shade. Williams Syndrome people have irises often described as "lacy". Their bodies don't make as much of the protein elastin. This protein is responsible for many organ functions including eye development.
There may be a coronation between elastin production at an early stage and eye color/pattern. 😁

I have blue eyes, and so does almost everyone in my family. My great grandfather on my dad's side had six boys, all of which have blue eyes. My mom's parent's have blue eyes, and so does she and her 2 sisters. My older sister(who has a different dad than me and my younger sister) has green eyes, while my younger sister and I(who share both parents) have blue eyes. The only people without blue eyes are the children of the couples where my family member married someone without blue eyes. We also have an astounding number of lefty's in my family. We think my great grandfather and grandfather on my dad's side were born lefty, but taught to be right handed because in the early 1900's and before it was seen as evil and part of the devil to be left-handed. Grandpa says he can't remember being taught to be right handed, but he feels more comfortable using his left for most things. I am completely ambidextrous. I can do fine motor movements with equal skill and comfort with both hands. My great grandfather died in 2016, before I really took interest in my genealogy, so I only have some brief stories of what early life was like for him in the Depression and WW2. Great grandpa had a Purple Heart and I was more interested in that growing up. I never got to ask him about which hand he prefers to use. It was his left side that was injured in WW2, so he had to use his right after that.

The point of this spiel: genetics are weird.

My mom has dark blue/green eyes. Her mom has bright blue eyes. Her father has brown eyes. A few of her grandparents had blue eyes. I’ve always been curious as to why her shade was so much darker than the other blue eyed family members in my family.

I grew up with distinctly hazel eyes and now have blue eyes. My blue eyes get duller the older I get, meaning more grey and less blue every year.
I have central heterochromia. I have grey on my outer ring and a green star burst formation around my pupil.

I think this is a prime example of that we should be vary of "facts". Not that we should be overly skeptical about established truths, but we shouldn't be dogmatic about anything that involves complex processes and systems. Being aware that most things probably have nuance and non-simple answers is so important for actually understanding the world, problems we encounter, and how we can solve it and what trade-offs we make.

I live in the city so I have never really driven, I have pretty good eyesight so I am grateful for no pressure. I look messed up to most people, security follows me in stores and I wont get served at a new bar. My eyes are squinty esp in bright sun / complete (light) cloud /overcast skies, I get the biggest squint headaches with overcast and bright fresh snow. More on that Research into Organoids. Dutch researchers are able to grow an organioid from a patients own cells. They can then use that organoid to test drugs to find a cure to the patients condition. One patient had the common varient of Cystic Fibrosis. The head researcher, grey a stomach organoid from the patients cells, then infected it with Cholera. The problem with Cholera and Cystic Fibrosis getting rid of excess fluid in the lungs. Since the organoid with Cholera didnt have a butt to get rid of the excess fluid, it allowed them to test drugs for Cholera to find out if it could solve that problem in the Organoid. It did, then they knew it would respond well to the treatment, so they started testing drugs that could deal with the Cystic Fibrosis and found a perfect drug that cured the disease. The treatment was rushed through approval by the Dutch government and is now the best treatment for the disease. The patient was completely cured of what was before an incurable disease that lead to death! He was able to return to Tennis which he loved, and a normal life. :) This is detailed on the iBiology channel. (nothing to do with me)

I'm a stem cell biologist and I can tell you that organoids have changed my field of research. As explained in the video, we make organoids by providing stem cells with different molecules so that they undergo certain aspects of development. For example, we can make brain organoids which mimic parts of the brain (I made a video about them). Brain organoids are tiny and not as complex as real brains but they help us to understand brain diseases and have recently been used to explain how schizophrenia arises!
